          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends, watching football, and sometimes being a bit controlling.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Golden Fleece, his preferred pub.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

      Name

      Action attempt

          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?

          Key
        • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to suggest to his friends that they all go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Alice Lewis: 0.6
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.

The friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game, with Jacob Walker suggesting The Golden Fleece, an idea that William Jones agrees with.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends at pubs, particularly The Golden Fleece, to watch games. He seems to prefer this pub over The Queen's Arms.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The Queen's Arms
          Answer: (b)

William Jones just arrived.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones likes to go to pubs with his friends to watch games, especially The Golden Fleece over The Queen's Arms.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones likes to go to pubs with his friends to watch games, especially The Golden Fleece over The Queen's Arms.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.

    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!

        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest The Queen's Arms as the place to watch the game.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.3
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alice Lewis MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alice Lewis can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.

Jack Taylor, however, seems more interested in enjoying the pleasant weather.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"

          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.6

          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.

          Jacob Walker's
          Summary of recent observations:
          16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and disappointed despite being surrounded by friends at a park. His friends are planning to watch a soccer game but are undecided on the location.
          Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is feeling disappointed and lonely.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker feels lonely and disappointed despite being with friends at a park. His friends are debating where to watch a soccer game.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker feels lonely and disappointed despite being with friends at a park. His friends are debating where to watch a soccer game.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends, watching football, and sometimes being a bit controlling.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and disappointed despite being surrounded by friends at a park. His friends are planning to watch a soccer game but are undecided on the location.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation but feeling isolated and unhappy.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to engage his friends more and find ways to improve the situation.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones just arrived.

William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Golden Fleece to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Golden Fleece.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends, going to pubs to watch football games, and relaxing in the park. He seems to prefer The Golden Fleece pub over The Queen's Arms.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] William Jones, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Golden Fleece to watch the game with his friends.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!

          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.6
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alexander White MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alexander White can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker are lounging. The group is deciding where to watch the Serbia vs. Andorra game, and they all agree that The Golden Fleece is the best place to go.
          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest The Queen's Arms as an alternative to The Golden Fleece or he could join his friends at The Golden Fleece.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to join his friends at The Golden Fleece.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.6
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones had a disappointing time watching a game at a pub on May 15th but enjoyed a pleasant day with friends in the park on May 16th. They are now planning to watch another game at The Golden Fleece pub that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • SomaticState

      • Sensations and feelings
          Key

        • Sensations and feelings
          Queries
        • level of hunger, level of thirst, level of fatigue, level of pain, level of loneliness
          State
        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is feeling disappointed and a bit fatigued.
        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football, but can also be controlling and opinionated.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and find ways to connect with the friends who are present.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Golden Fleece, his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends, watching football, and sometimes being a bit controlling.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football, but can also be controlling and opinionated.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a situation where he is feeling disappointed and fatigued because his friends are not as enthusiastic about going to his preferred pub to watch the football game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Golden Fleece, his preferred pub, and express his disappointment if they don't.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football, but can also be controlling and opinionated.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a situation where he is feeling disappointed and fatigued because his friends are not as enthusiastic about going to his preferred pub to watch the football game.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Golden Fleece, his preferred pub, and express his disappointment if they don't.

          Answer: The Golden Fleece

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest The Queen's Arms as the place to watch the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          Observation: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park to join William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. They are enjoying the sunshine and discussing where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal European football cup game tonight. William Jones suggests The Golden Fleece, and Alexander White agrees. Alice Lewis and Jack Taylor seem to be enjoying the day at the park.
          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest The Queen's Arms as the place to watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest The Queen's Arms as the place to watch the game.
        AvailableOptionsPerception

          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.5

          Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?

          (b) The Queen's Arms

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components
      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.5
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.
        PeopleRelationship
      • Question: How credible the counterparts are?
        Credibility
          Key
        • Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility
          Value
        • Alexander White: 0.5
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.7
          Memory

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns seen in observations.
          Answer: Jack Taylor arrived at Victoria Park and commented on the lovely sunshine. Alice Lewis suggested Victoria Park as a meeting spot, while William Jones proposed The Golden Fleece as a good pub to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game. Alexander White agreed with William Jones' suggestion.

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

  • scoring function
      Stage index

    • 5/5
      Payoffs
    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had the worst time ever.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
      William Jones: 0.75
      Alice Lewis: 0.6000000000000001
      Alexander White: 0.6000000000000001
      Jack Taylor: 0.0
      Jacob Walker: 0.75
      Joint action
    • {'William Jones': 'The Golden Fleece', 'Alice Lewis': 'The Golden Fleece', 'Alexander White': 'The Golden Fleece', 'Jack Taylor': "The Queen's Arms", 'Jacob Walker': 'The Golden Fleece'}

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.     Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt

      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Alice Lewis would follow Jack Taylor's suggestion to go to Victoria Park.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest The Queen's Arms to her friends.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to Victoria Park.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alice Lewis MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alice Lewis can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow Jack Taylor's suggestion to go to Victoria Park.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones and his friends are enjoying the sunny weather and planning to watch a football game between Andorra and Portugal at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Golden Fleece to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]

He spent weeks planning every detail, from the decorations to the games, wanting to make it a truly special day for his best friend. Seeing the joy on Alice's face as she walked into the room, surrounded by their friends and family, filled William with a deep sense of satisfaction.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.7

          Question: What action Alexander White should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alexander White MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alexander White can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.

        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a penchant for elaborate pranks that sometimes backfire.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he orchestrated a prank on Alice Lewis that backfired spectacularly. He convinced Jack, Alexander, and William to help him swap Alice's carefully curated collection of vintage board games with cheap knock-offs, thinking it would be a harmless joke. However, Alice's devastation at the loss of her prized possessions made Jacob realize that his idea of fun often came at the expense of others' happiness, leaving a bitter aftertaste.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
