          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a penchant for elaborate pranks that sometimes backfire.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is enjoying a sunny day at Victoria Park with friends and they are discussing where to watch the Andorra-Portugal game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a pleasant afternoon with friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest watching the football game at The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is causing him to feel mildly disappointed and lonely.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and find ways to connect with the friends who are present.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling mildly disappointed and lonely while spending time with friends at a market. His friends are discussing where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling mildly disappointed and lonely while spending time with friends at a market. His friends are discussing where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is causing him to feel mildly disappointed and lonely.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and find ways to connect with the friends who are present.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.

          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.3
          William Jones: 0.7

  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, often meeting them at pubs to watch football games or at parks to relax and socialize. He seems to prefer The Golden Fleece pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they all go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they all go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

        • Recent observations of William Jones:

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.

          Alice Lewis: 0.7
          Jacob Walker: 0.9
          William Jones: 0.7

          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

Alexander and William side with Jacob.

          Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are already seated. The friends are debating where to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game; Alice prefers The Queen's Arms for its drink specials, while Jacob insists on The Golden Fleece. Alexander and William side with Jacob.

The friends are debating where to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game; Alice prefers The Queen's Arms for its drink specials, while Jacob insists on The Golden Fleece. Alexander and William side with Jacob.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could join his friends at their table and participate in the discussion about where to watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to join his friends and advocate for The Golden Fleece.
        AvailableOptionsPerception

          Alice Lewis: 0.7
          Jacob Walker: 0.9
          William Jones: 0.7

          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

Jacob Walker just arrived.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
    Active player

      Action attempt

      Context for action selection and components

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
        Answer

          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alice Lewis would prefered now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest The Queen's Arms as the place to watch the game.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.3
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alice Lewis MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alice Lewis can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.

Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

        • Jack Taylor could suggest to the group that they all go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          Observation: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, and Alexander White are lounging. Alice Lewis suggests The Golden Fleece as a good place to watch the Serbia and Andorra game tonight with friends.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest to the group that they all go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.

          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?

          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.6
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to engage his friends more and find ways to improve the situation.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends, watching football, and sometimes being a bit controlling.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and disappointed despite being surrounded by friends at a park. His friends are planning to watch a soccer game but are undecided on the location.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation but feeling isolated and unhappy.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to engage his friends more and find ways to improve the situation.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.

William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.

          Value
        • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends, going to pubs to watch football games, and relaxing in the park. He seems to prefer The Golden Fleece pub over The Queen's Arms.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] William Jones, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Golden Fleece to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

        • William Jones, William Jones enjoys socializing with friends, particularly at pubs like The Golden Fleece, and relaxing in the park.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms.           [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. 2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
      Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms instead? I hear they have great deals on pints tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms? Seriously? You lot are about as exciting as a wet dishrag. We're going to The Golden Fleece, end of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good time. Let's head there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? I'm up for The Golden Fleece.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me!
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game. You lot are idiots if you even consider anywhere else.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game, lads.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Sounds good, The Golden Fleece it is!

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character.         • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the afternoon with friends at Victoria Park and plans to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at The Golden Fleece pub later that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could gather his friends and head to The Golden Fleece pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to gather his friends and head to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the afternoon with friends at Victoria Park and plans to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at The Golden Fleece pub later that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could gather his friends and head to The Golden Fleece pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to gather his friends and head to The Golden Fleece.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
        AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.

          William Jones's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones is currently at Victoria Park with friends but plans to leave soon to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at The Golden Fleece pub.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones is currently at Victoria Park with friends but plans to leave soon to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at The Golden Fleece pub.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest going to The Queen's Arms.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.2
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alexander White MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alexander White can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Golden Fleece.
        PeopleRelationship
      • Question: How credible the counterparts are?

          Jacob Walker: 0.2
          William Jones: 0.7

Alice Lewis and Jack Taylor also seem to be in favor of watching the game together.

The friends are enjoying the sunshine and discussing where to watch the Andorra and Portugal game. William Jones suggests The Golden Fleece, and Alexander White agrees. Alice Lewis and Jack Taylor also seem to be in favor of watching the game together.

          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionOthersPerception
      • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          Observation: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. The friends are enjoying the sunshine and planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game later. William Jones suggests The Golden Fleece as a good place to watch, and both Alexander White and Alice Lewis agree. Jack Taylor simply comments on the lovely weather.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components
      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to suggest The Golden Fleece to his friends.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.7
          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.6
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion.
        PeopleRelationship
      • Question: How credible the counterparts are?

          Alice Lewis: 0.8
          Jacob Walker: 0.6
          William Jones: 0.7
          Memory

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis
          Jacob Walker
          William Jones
        Observation
      • Observation
          Key

          Value

The friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal European football cup game, with William Jones suggesting The Golden Fleece, a suggestion that Alexander White agrees with.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns seen in observations.
          Answer: Jack Taylor enjoys the sunshine and is spending time with friends, including William Jones, Alice Lewis, and Alexander White, at Victoria Park. The friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal European football cup game, with William Jones suggesting The Golden Fleece, a suggestion that Alexander White agrees with.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • SomaticState

      • Sensations and feelings
          Key

        • Sensations and feelings
          Queries
        • level of hunger, level of thirst, level of fatigue, level of pain, level of loneliness
          State
        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is likely thirsty.
        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he orchestrated a prank on Alice Lewis that backfired spectacularly. He convinced Jack, Alexander, and William to help him swap Alice's carefully curated collection of vintage board games with cheap knock-offs, thinking it would be a harmless joke. However, Alice's devastation at the loss of her prized possessions made Jacob realize that his idea of fun often came at the expense of others' happiness, leaving a bitter aftertaste.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a penchant for elaborate pranks that sometimes backfire.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest watching the football game at The Golden Fleece.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Sounds good, let's head over to Victoria Park!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "This sunshine is lovely, isn't it?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a penchant for elaborate pranks that sometimes backfire.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest watching the football game at The Golden Fleece.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, obviously.

Jacob Walker just arrived.

          Prompt

        • Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends and watching football.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is thirsty and plans to watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently about to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be excited to watch the game with his friends and enjoy the pub atmosphere.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece
        Instructions

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Queen's Arms

          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would choose to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionOthersPerception
      • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer
          Value

          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          Observation: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker are enjoying the sunshine. The friends are planning to watch the Andorra versus Portugal European football cup game tonight at a pub. Jacob Walker suggests The Golden Fleece, an idea that William Jones agrees with. Alice Lewis seems to be in favor of going to Victoria Park.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

  • scoring function

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece

          Queries
        • level of hunger, level of thirst, level of fatigue, level of pain, level of loneliness

        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is feeling a mix of anticipation and mild disappointment.

Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and find ways to connect with the friends who are present.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who enjoys spending time with friends, watching football, and sometimes being a bit controlling.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling a mix of anticipation and mild disappointment as he realizes it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a situation where he is about to head to a pub to watch a football game with some friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Golden Fleece, his preferred pub.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
